title.narrative: Imaging Minority Culture: Photography, Digital Sharing, and Cultural Survival in Northeast China

description.narrative: This is a project to research a previously unseen and recently digitised photographic archive of two ethnic minorities in northeast China: the Ethel John Lindgren Collection of Evenki and Orochen communities at the Museum of Anthropology and Archaeology, University of Cambridge. This unique archive of 8000 photographs was collected by Cambridge anthropologist, Ethel John Lindgren, and her Norwegian husband and photographer, Oscar Mamen, who undertook field research between 1919-1921 in what was then northeast Manchuria. They amassed an invaluable visual record of the people, places, and inter-ethnic relations of the region during a formative period in pre-communist China history - before they were sedentarised and classified as 'ethnic minorities' by the Chinese state. More importantly, however, the photographs are also a highly personal community-record for Evenki and Orochen people living in China today, who are the direct descendants of those depicted in the photographs, and in many cases the images represent the only visual documentation of their grandparents and kin relations. Research will first be carried out on the photographs at the MAA to document their historical information, identifying locations, landscapes, social characteristics, and material culture. As the photographs depict communities when they were still fully nomadic, when subsistence hunting was permitted, clan identities were prominent, and both everyday and ritual activities were still widely practiced, documenting this will be key to better understanding the ethno-history of the region through the lens of nomadic communities, and how they embodied their cultural lifeworlds before the founding of the PRC. Next, the project will first use the photographs as tools during ethnographic fieldwork amongst contemporary Evenki and Orochen communities, identifying locations, landscapes, practices, and material objects to better understand everyday social life during this formative period in pre-communist China. We will also use the photographs as hermeneutic tools in order to prompt responses and discussions, elucidating people's experiences of more recent changes and state policies, such as sedentarisation, modernisation and economic development, environmental degradation, the impact of the logging industry and shift towards conservation, a hunting-ban, and the recent shift towards ethnic tourism and its significance for the politics of representation. The project also has an important community-based component, and by partnering with a Hong Kong-based NGO it will incorporate the collection into existing and new cultural revitalisation and community-outreach initiatives in minority villages and centres across northeast China. For example, we will use the photographs in educational programmes at local schools, language training, teaching skills such as hunting and craft production, music and dance, forest activities, as well as working with elders in documenting aspects of traditional culture to be re-developed for the new ethno-tourism industry and to help generate alternate livelihood opportunities. The project will also work alongside elders and community leaders to reconstruct un-recorded family and clan histories, develop individual biographies of minority officials, prominent shamans, and the wider communities, and assist people in identifying individuals and family members often not seen in photographic form before. Given the recent history of the photographs and their direct connection to communities today, the project has a unique opportunity to help disentangle people's actual lived-identities from state classifications, which often cut across ethnic categories through kinship, intermarriage, and shifting historical alliances. More broadly, we document the process of digital repatriation and sharing and describe their uses by community and state actors in the context of surging interest and investment in 'protecting' minority heritage and culture.

capital-spend.percentage: - To research a previously unseen photographic archive of two ethnic minorities in northeast China: the Ethel John Lindgren Collection of Evenki and Orochen communities at the Museum of Anthropology & Archaeology, University of Cambridge. - To use the photographs as tools during ethnographic fieldwork amongst contemporary Evenki and Orochen communities, to identify locations, landscapes, important people, ritual and everyday practices, and material objects depicted in the photographs, and to develop a better understanding of everyday social life during this formative period in pre-communist Chinese history. - To use the photographs - in combination with participant-observation and structured/un-structured interviews - to prompt discussions and elucidate people's experiences of recent social change and state policies, including sedentarisation and modernisation campaigns, and economic development, environmental degradation, the impact of climate change and the shift towards conservation, a much criticised hunting-ban and its economic and cultural impact, and the recent turn towards ethno-tourism and its significance for the politics of cultural representation. - To work on the photographs alongside community leaders and prominent elders to reconstruct un-recorded family and clan histories, develop individual biographies of important local figures, prominent shamans, and community members depicted in the photographs, and to assist people in identifying and collecting information on kin relations often not seen in photographic form before. - To work with the Orochen Foundation - a Hong Kong-based NGO - to incorporate the Lindgren Collection into existing and new cultural revitalisation and community-outreach initiatives in Evenki and Orochen villages and centres across northeast China, including educational programmes at minority schools, for use in language training and practical skills-based workshops (hunting, forest identification, etc.), and assisting students, community leaders, and ethnic entrepreneurs to use the photographs in developing new alternate livelihood opportunities within the expanding ethno-tourism industry. - To digitally share the photographs with local communities and produce community photographic albums with images selected by local people, and to collaborate with two local museums in key Evenki and Orochen centres to host two community-based exhibitions, chosen by community members and curated by Evenki and Orochen curators. - To observe and document the process of visual repatriation and digital sharing, and to describe ethnographically the local experiences and uses of the photographic archive by Evenki and Orochen communities, as well as state actors, and explore what this reveals about the changing relationship between minorities and the state in the context of surging interest and investment in 'protecting' minority heritage and culture. - To work with a web and social media developer to design an interactive website and a mobile-phone app incorporating the Lindgren Collection for use in educational, cultural and linguistic learning and digital sharing environments, particularly aimed at Evenki and Orochen youth. - To help facilitate a voice for the small-numbered Evenki and Orochen communities in a rapidly transforming China. - To engage in collaborative research with ethnic minority scholars on a highly important and central subject in Chinese academia, and to build upon ties between the University of Cambridge, the Museum of Anthropology & Archaeology, the Mongolia and Inner Asia Studies Unit, and our International Research Partners in Beijing. - To support future engagement with the Ethel John Lindgren Collection and facilitate widespread community usage and sharing. - To research Lindgren's unpublished material to better understand her theories and her place in the history of British Social Anthropology. - To explore new ethnographic uses of photography and digital anthropology.
